title: Magnolia obovata
text:
Magnolia obovata, the Japanese cucumber tree, Japanese bigleaf magnolia, or Japanese whitebark magnolia, is a species of "<a href="Magnolia">Magnolia</a>", native to <a href="Japan">Japan</a> and the adjacent <a href="Kurile%20Islands">Kurile Islands</a>. It grows at altitudes near sea level up to 1,800 m in mixed broadleaf forests.
Description.
It is a medium-sized <a href="deciduous">deciduous</a> <a href="tree">tree</a> 15–30 m tall, with slate grey bark. The <a href="leaf">leaves</a> are large, 16–38 cm (rarely to 50 cm) long and 9–20 cm (rarely 25 cm) broad, leathery, green above, silvery or greyish <a href="Pubescent%20%28botany%29">pubescent</a> below, and with an acute apex. They are held in <a href="Whorl%20%28botany%29">whorls</a> of five to eight at the end of each shoot. The <a href="flower">flower</a>s are also large, cup-shaped, 15–20 cm diameter, with 9-12 creamy, fleshy <a href="tepal">tepal</a>s, red <a href="stamen">stamen</a>s; they have a strong scent, and are produced in early summer after the leaves expand. The <a href="fruit">fruit</a> is an oblong-cylindric aggregate of <a href="follicle%20%28fruit%29">follicle</a>s 12–20 cm long and 6 cm broad, bright pinkish red, each follicle containing one or two black <a href="seed">seed</a>s with a fleshy orange-red coating.
Uses.
The <a href="wood">wood</a> is strong, light, and easy to work, sought by craftsmen. In parts of Japan, the large leaves are used for wrapping food, and also as a makeshift dish to grill meat or vegetables, such as leeks, mushrooms, and miso in "hoba <a href="miso">miso</a>".
